item.title: Derby.js - The Ready() Function, and Adding Client-Side Scripts to your App
item.description: I’ve found a neat feature of derby dealing with the ready() function. I’ve been creating a derby app, and in my application I need to load up a client-side calendar. With a standard HTML web page this is straightforward thing to do. On the page you wanted the calendar, you would include the client js for the calendar, some code to load it, and that would be that. Derby introduced some complexity to this relatively simple task. On my first attempt, I put my scripts in the section of the page that I needed the calendar on. I added a script to load the calendar as well. When I went to the url of the page, it loaded immediately. Success! (I thought).

item.title: Derby.js - Starting out with Components; Creating a Twitter Bootstrap Input Component
item.description:
In working with Twitter Bootstrap Forms, one of my favorite ways to lay out a form is using the Horizontal form layout. The layout requires a bit of css/html to get each of the form elements (the text boxes and what not) to play nicely. To add form elements to the horizontal form layout, you need the following html structure for each field:

<div class="control-group"><!-- additional classes here to change state -->
  <label class="control-label">INPUT_LABEL_TEXT_HERE</label>
  <div class="controls">
    <input type="text" /> <!-- This is the control you want to display -->
    <span class="help-inline">ERROR_OR_INFORMATIONAL_MESSAGE_HERE</span>
  </div>
</div>

That’s a hefty amount of markup to copy and paste all over your pristine views. Which makes this a great place to use a Component.

item.title: Posting an IEnumerable of Interfaces back from your Views by extending the DefaultModelBinder
item.description:
